prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The first step in maintaining confidentiality is to be familiar with the information that should be protected. Any information of a business, commercial, industrial, strategic, technical or scientific nature may receive legal protection. Where information consists of a concrete formula, recipe, process or mechanism, it is likely to receive court protection. Almost all documentary information of this type, including customer lists, data, plans or drawings, is entitled to legal protection from misuse. However, the courts are increasingly acknowledging the importance of information regarding secret bids, the compensation of key employees, corporate financial or investment strategy, policy changes, and marketing strategies.[1]

Every business should maintain a current inventory of all confidential information. In order to keep the list current, periodic audits should be conducted. The inventory list should include, at a minimum, the types of information involved. Further details such as storage medium, location, number of copies and individuals with access can be included, along with any other important facts. It goes without saying that the inventory list is itself confidential.

Using the guidelines set out in Chapter 3, businesses should identify corporate information which is capable of receiving protection and then decide what level of protection is appropriate. Audits should be conducted on a regular basis. An ongoing review process is particularly important in the constantly changing environment in which businesses now find themselves operating. It is recommended that a review take place at least annually. However, numerous factors such as, but not limited to, corporate transactions, consolidations, strategic alliances, the departure of key employees, globalization, the development of new products, entering into new business areas and technological advances, may trigger the need to conduct additional reviews. These reviews should be completed as part of a broader consideration of the company's intellectual property rights.
Lansing Linde Ltd. v. Kerr, [1991] 1 All E.R. 418 (C.A.).
